{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2985711,"name":"Barkın Var","username":"barkinvar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/barkinvar/{size}/171468_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T20:20:05.336Z","cooked":"

Because of the structure of the cascade elevator, carriage will be moving two times faster than a continuous elevator. I am using the JVN calculator and I did set the travel distance as half the distance of the movement of the carriage to get the real movement time. However, I couldn’t calculate the total load. Is the total load 2*(weight of carriage+weight of game piece)+weight of stage 1 or just double of all three weights?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T20:20:30.144Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":744,"reads":264,"readers_count":263,"score":3787.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398784,"topic_slug":"cascade-elevator-load-calculation","display_username":"Barkın Var","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9483 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cascade-elevator-load-calculation/398784/1","custom_user_title":"9483 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2985721,"name":"Clayton Ramsey","username":"ClayTownR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T20:33:17.570Z","cooked":"

Your first guess is correct - one way of thinking about it is that the cascade pulley system will double the force from the carriage on your drive pulley. In general, stage 1 exerts a load of 1x its weight, stage 2 exerts 2x, and so on (for higher-stage elevators).

Note that a continuous elevator (unlike a cascade elevator) will not have this multiplication, however, the load will vary throughout the length of travel.

Also: I’ll add a little bit of design advice from my personal experience with elevators: having only one rope on an elevator that wide is just asking for racking. It would be best to have two sets of ropes to keep the elevator balanced.

ClayTownR:

about it is that the cascade pulley system will double the force from the carriage on your drive pulley. In general, stage 1 exerts a load of 1x its weight, stage 2 exerts 2x, and so on (for higher-stage elevators).

Note that a continuous elevator (unlike a cascade elevator) will not have this multiplication, however, the load will vary throughout the length of travel.

Also: I’ll add a little bit of design advice from my personal experience with elevators: having only one rope on an elevator that wide is just asking for racking. It would be best to have two sets of ropes to keep the elevator balanced.

Thanks for the explanation. I got the elevator design from google photos just to demonstrate the stages . When I drew the free body diagram of the elevator i found the first result. However, while reading the CD posts i saw that some teams calculated it as if there was 1:2 reduction. I believe they did not calculate the correct results but it is not a big deal to have some extra torque.

I am using the JVN’s calculator but it does not calculte applied load. If I was designing a continuous elevator it would be just the total weight of the elevator + game piece. However, I am designing cascade elevator which is two times faster if it is two stages. That is why I have to calculate the total load and that is what I asked for.
